posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Signal WhatsApp Telegram
You can hide your phone number from other users You can’t hide your phone number from other users You can hide your phone number from other users
End-to-end encrypts all chats End-to-end encrypts all chats End-to-end encrypts only “secret chats” but not regular one-on-one messages and never group messages
Calls, video calls, group calls and group video calls are end-to-end encrypted Calls, video calls, group calls and group video calls are end-to-end encrypted Calls and video calls are only end-to-end encrypted if it’s a one-on-one call, but in groups they are not encrypted. Telegram also has voice chats which are slightly different from voice calls, and voice chats are not end-to-end encrypted.
Encrypts how long you call and with who Whatsapp knows how long you call with whom and this information is most likely being used to make money off Telegram knows how long you call with whom
Your profile picture, name and description are also encrypted, the servers can’t see them Your profile picture, name and status are not encrypted and most likely get used to make money off Your profile picture, name and status are not encrypted
When you send a GIF Giphy can’t see who you are Giphy sees every GIF you use and sells that data to make money off Giphy sees every GIF you use and sells that data to make money off
In most cases Signal does not store who is sending to whom (due to a technology called “sealed sender” which is enabled on most messages they only see the current IP-address of the sender but nothing else) WhatsApp can always see who sends messages at what time to whom Telegram can always see who sends messages at what time to whom
Signal can’t see which stickers you use WhatsApp knows which sticker packs you have and can also see which stickers you use Telegram knows which sticker packs you have and can also see which stickers you use, unless you use them in a secret chat
Signal does not know which groups you have joined WhatsApp knows which groups you have joined Telegram knows which groups you have joined
Signal doesn’t pretend it can block screenshots on the other people’s phone WhatsApp doesn’t pretend it can block screenshots on other people’s phone Telegram attempts to block taking screenshots for ‘secret chats’ which could create a false sense of security. Reality is that blocking someone else from saving chats or media is not possible.
The stuff on metadata should be changed from does not know to does not store.
How does Signal encrypt how long you call?

Like I understand Signal Signal call establishment is the same as sending message. Signal server must know the recipient. Then peer-to-peer communication is established and when call is finished, I don’t think Signal server is involved.

Signal call can be established Signal server as proxy and all network traffic travels through Signal servers. Idea is to not reveal receiver your IP address. But you reveal some additional info to Signal server like when you finish the call. They probably do not store this info how long call was in progress, but you never know.

Since there was just a discussion between Will Cathcart and Whittaker about WhatsApp being as secure as Signal, I think a thread like this one is important, and should be updated regularly.

From what I have read, Meredith Whittaker did not mention all important differences, and here, besides the fact it’s all old from 2022, I also think it’s far from being complete.

Two differences, which I think are important, when talking about security, are those two:

  1. Using WhatsApp, it might happen, that complete chats end up unencrypted in a backup. This depends on your settings, of course, and you can encrypt your backups, but especially in group chats, you do not have the control, what other people do.
    Signal does not participate in iCloud or Google Drive backups, and this, is much more secure here.

  2. WhatsApp offers a web client, which is less secure than the apps on different operatings systems.
    Signal does not offer any web service, and thus, is more secure.

And meanwhile you can hide your phone number in Signal, so the table above is no longer correct.

posts.name: Tiwo Satriatama
posts.cooked:
I think these aspects are important differences

a0ef76ab-93be-49e9-b272-d2f00ae08d4f1136×2000 441 KB

Larissa:

And meanwhile you can hide your phone number in Signal, so the table above is no longer correct.

Fixed and moved to the Wiki category.

tiwosatriatama:

I think these aspects are important differences

It seems we have different priorities.

For me, the content of my messages is what matters.
If I have a group chat with 10 girls, and I know three of them back up their entire iPhone including WhatsApp chats unencrypted to their Windows computer, 2 back up everything to iCloud and did not activate encryption, I know the entire group is not private.

In contrast to this, I really do not care much about the meta data. They know I wrote you a message at 1:00, and it took me 6 minutes to write. Who cares, as long as the content is private.

That is why I missed the backup problem in her statement.

Larissa:

In contrast to this, I really do not care much about the meta data. They know I wrote you a message at 1:00, and it took me 6 minutes to write. Who cares, as long as the content is private.

Maybe you should care.

Electronic Frontier Foundation – 7 Jun 13

Why Metadata Matters

In response to the recent news reports about the National Security Agency's surveillance program, President Barack Obama said today, "When it comes to telephone calls, nobody is listening to your telephone calls." Instead, the government was just...

Let’s take a closer look at what they are saying:

They know you rang a phone sex service at 2:24 am and spoke for 18 minutes. But they don’t know what you talked about.
They know you called the suicide prevention hotline from the Golden Gate Bridge. But the topic of the call remains a secret.
They know you spoke with an HIV testing service, then your doctor, then your health insurance company in the same hour. But they don’t know what was discussed.
They know you received a call from the local NRA office while it was having a campaign against gun legislation, and then called your senators and congressional representatives immediately after. But the content of those calls remains safe from government intrusion.
They know you called a gynecologist, spoke for a half hour, and then called the local Planned Parenthood’s number later that day. But nobody knows what you spoke about.

Sorry, your phone records—oops, "so-called metadata"—can reveal a lot more about the content of your calls than the government is implying. Metadata provides enough context to know some of the most intimate details of your lives.

The New York Review of Books

'We Kill People Based on Metadata' | David Cole

A bill to rein in NSA spying on Americans’ metadata has wide bipartisan support in Congress. It is an important first step, but it addresses only one part of the NSA’s vast surveillance activities.

As NSA General Counsel Stewart Baker has said, “metadata absolutely tells you everything about somebody’s life. If you have enough metadata, you don’t really need content.” When I quoted Baker at a recent debate at Johns Hopkins University, my opponent, General Michael Hayden, former director of the NSA and the CIA, called Baker’s comment “absolutely correct,” and raised him one, asserting, “We kill people based on metadata.”

'We Kill People Based on Metadata' | David Cole | The New York Review of Books
The Snowden Leaks and the Public | Alan Rusbridger | The New York Review of Books

posts.cooked:
DirkPitt1:

Maybe you should care.

We kill people on metadata is old - though not clear what exactly he meant.
Do you get killed, when you write a WhatsApp message to a specific person? No.

The only thing which happened a few times were things like: ah, we located (also metadata) the phone of Bin Laden (this is an example), so he must be there, too, let’s make a drone attack.
But Bin Laden put the phone in some hospital before and was completely elsewhere - which shows how dumb the entire thinking is.

Metadata alone doesn’t give you anything, and I believe the NSA only once claimed their importance, because they were hiding the fact they indeed DID listen to phone calls.

Two times a week I write my sister. Also about two times a week I write my veterinarian. Do I care anyone knows that? No, it’s not hard to find out that I have a sister, neither that I have a veterinarian.
But I really don’t want anyone to know WHAT I write to my sister.

And here lies the problem:
Using WhatsApp or iMessage, you are never sure about the latter, because unencrypted backups do exactly mean, that someone COULD read the contents (probably no one will do it, there is just a small probability).

Using Signal, you are more secure. Okay, someone could hack your phone (then nothing is secure anymore), or my sister could use something else than the official Signal client (but she doesn’t). But so far, your content is really secure.

It’s really strange, that some people nowadays seem to care more about metadata than the content.

Larissa:

Do you get killed, when you write a WhatsApp message to a specific person? No.

Sure, probably none of us here needs to be afraid of US drone strike. But if someone deem metadata so reliable to let people decide to liquidate other people based on metadata, things that can be extrapolated from them shouldn’t be underestimated.

Larissa:

Metadata alone doesn’t give you anything

One again I send you to examples provided by EFF. None of them mightn’t apply to you personally but they show how you can fairly reliably guess content of your communication, just knowing metadata.

Larissa:

Two times a week I write my sister. Also about two times a week I write my veterinarian. Do I care anyone knows that? No, it’s not hard to find out that I have a sister, neither that I have a veterinarian.

So you have established patterns of communication. Even better if someone wants to use your metadata against you. Use your imagination and let’s see this hypothetical scenario: some important person gets killed and the police, lacking any other clues, tries to see whose cell phones were nearby the crime scene at given time. Your sister’s number comes up. Of course it’s just one of many more phones present in the location.

But some inquisitive officer digs deeper. Your sister called you less than 20 minutes from suspected death time. This gets interesting but still could be a mere coincidence. Anyway, the investigator digs even deeper and sees that your communications has a pattern - you call each other every Monday and Friday between 3 and 6 p.m. Week of the crime didn’t start in any other way. You spoke at Monday, just as you usually do. But this particular call took place Wednesday at 1:20 a.m., which is a clear break from tour established routine. Bullseye! It’s just a n indirect proof but it’s good enough.

Your sister get implicated in the murder case as a potential murderer and you as her accomplice. If you can’t prove otherwise, you can have circumstantial prosecution. If you’re lucky, everything ends fine. If not… well, even the best judiciary systems can make mistakes.

I let you came up with a a bad scenario, involving metadata and your vet, yourself.

Larissa:

It’s really strange, that some people nowadays seem to care more about metadata than the content.

Not more. Simply just as much.

I really don’t want to make you turn paranoid about metadata or else… If your threat model says metadata are irrelevant, it’s perfectly fine as long as you’re aware of potential risks. Hopefully you’ll understand why some people seem to care about metadata so much.

Larissa:

We kill people on metadata is old - though not clear what exactly he meant.
Do you get killed, when you write a WhatsApp message to a specific person? No.

It’s nice to live with such a privileged worldview. You should consider the people of Gaza as an extreme far away example from home.
